Award.AwardTitle: University of Alaska Fairbanks/Sikuliaq Oceanographic Instrumentation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) operates R/V Sikuliaq, a 261-foot, global class ice-capable oceanographic research vessel owned by the NSF as part of the UNOLS fleet. Sikuliaq provides a general-purpose platform for multidisciplinary research missions from polar to temperate latitudes. The ship was delivered in 2014 and has completed three years of funded operations. UAF requests funds to purchase and install shipboard scientific support equipment that would be custom engineered to enhance the vessel's capability in support of NSF-sponsored research to be undertaken on Sikuliaq in the future.

In 2017, R/V Sikuliaq completed 271 days, 178 (66%) of which were for NSF. In 2018, the vessel is scheduled to sail 249 days with 63% (157 days) of the schedule for NSF. With this proposal, UAF provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Oceanographic Instrumentation:

1) Echosounder Calibraton Control System $13,421
2) 911plus CTD and sensors $113,615
3) Simrad EK80 Transceivers $221,332
4) RDI Ocean Surveyor 38 KHz ADCP $172,790
5) 12 KHz transducer $7,530
$528,688

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Award 1822954 provided funding for the following system upgrades aboard the NSF polar class 5 research vessel Sikuliaq operated by the University of Alaska, Fairbanks.

  • Echosounder Calibration Control System
  • Seabird Electronics (SBE) 911plus CTD and Sensors for Multi Opening and Closing Net with Environmental Sampling Sensors (MOCNESS) upgrade
  • Simrad EK80 Wideband Transceivers
  • 12 kHz Transducer for Communications

 

Echosounder Calibration Control System

A system of three downriggers and a control station have been installed aboard the vessel. The control station was installed near the EK80 sonar work station and allows local control of payout and pay-in of the three downriggers. The downriggers are installed on the upper deck and positioned to form a triangle around the EK80 sonar array. The calibration sphere is attached to lines from all three downriggers and suspended under the EK80 sonar array. The sonar operator controls pay-in and payout of the downriggers which allows them to position the calibration sphere in the sound cones of the 5 transducers that make up the EK80 sonar array. Instillation of this system has cut the time needed to calibrate the EK80 sonar array in half as it is more efficient than relying on personnel stationed at each downrigger responding to verbal commands over UHF radio. Installation has resulted in a 75% reduction in personnel needed in the calibration operation.  Calibration of acoustic instruments like the EK80 is fundamental to the quantitative use of its data for estimating the abundance of biomass in a well-described environment. Initial calibrations show potential differences between the theoretical specifications of instrument performance versus actual performance. Regularly repeating calibrations over time allows instrument performance to be monitored to detect changes due to the environment or component dynamics

 

Seabird Electronics (SBE) 911plus CTD and Sensors

Shipboard Technical Support (STS) group from Scripps Institution of Oceanography developed an underwater electronics interface and topside software package as an upgrade to the Multi Opening and Closing Net with Environmental Sampling Sensors (MOCNESS). This upgrade allowed for a Seabird Electronics (SBE) 911 CTD to be integrate into the MOCNESS platform. The SBE 911 CTD is capable of accommodating multiple sensors far beyond that of the original underwater interface delivered with MOCNESS. The SBE 911 CTD is able to provide 24 samples per second from each sensor. The original MOCNESS hardware provided 1 sample every four seconds from each of its sensors when tethered to the electro mechanical oceanographic cable/s deployed aboard SIKULIAQ. The newly upgraded system has been deployed in the Gulf of Alaska and the Beaufort Sea.  

 

Simrad EK80 Wideband Transceivers

The EK60 split-beam sonar array that was delivered with the ship was upgraded to the next generation wideband EK80 split-beam sonar array. This was via software upgrades, replacement of one of the five transducer in the array and replacing all five General Purpose Transceivers (GPTs) with Wideband Transceivers (WBTs). The system exploits wideband echosounder technology where backscatter levels from a range of frequencies are processed, providing enhanced target information. The frequency sweep that is transmitted ?also known as a chirp ? in combination with advanced signal processing gives exceptional data quality with increased signal to noise ratio and range resolution. A more detailed frequency response allows scientists to identify fish and zooplankton species more accurately.

 

12 kHz Transducer for Communications

A 4-24 kHz transducer was purchased and installed on the ship?s acoustic centerboard. The transducer has been paired with Sikuliaq?s Benthos universal acoustic modem. This system allows Sikuliaq science parties to communicate acoustically with compatible underwater instrumentation. The transducer has also been used with science supplied transcievers. The new transducer has improved the ship?s capability of acoustically communicating with deployed scientific instrumentation.
